sgcool_label_text:This wooden stand was likely to have been used as a stand for a censor
 and placed in a prominent position on an altar. It consists of three platforms
 each framed by borders decorated with abstract vegetal designs in mother-of-pearl. Despite the adoption of numerous Malay cultural practices
 such as language and dress
 the religion practiced by the Peranakans was essentially a traditional Chinese form
 which was polytheistic in nature and incorporated elements of ancestor worship
 Buddhism and Taoism. Blackwood furniture with mother-of-pearl inlays was extremely popular with wealthy Peranakans in the 19th century.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This wooden stand was likely to have been used as a stand for a censor, and placed in a prominent position on an altar. It consists of three platforms, each framed by borders decorated with abstract vegetal designs in mother-of-pearl. Despite the adoption of numerous Malay cultural practices, such as language and dress, the religion practiced by the Peranakans was essentially a traditional Chinese form, which was polytheistic in nature and incorporated elements of ancestor worship, Buddhism and Taoism. Blackwood furniture with mother-of-pearl inlays was extremely popular with wealthy Peranakans in the 19th century.
